skills.label: Can use a field guide to look up species by visual features
Can identify at least 5 local tree species by leaf shape, bark, and silhouette
Can identify at least 5 local bird species by sight and call
Can identify common animal tracks and signs (scat, browse marks, burrows)
Can use a compass and topographic map to navigate a trail
Can read natural weather indicators (cloud types, wind shifts, barometric changes)
Can maintain a structured field journal with dated observations, sketches, and measurements
Can describe major habitat types (forest, wetland, grassland, riparian) and their key features
Can use a water quality testing kit to measure pH, dissolved oxygen, and turbidity
Can identify common water pollutants and their sources from test results
Can conduct a systematic species survey using transect or quadrat methods
Can calculate species richness and diversity indices from survey data
Can map a local food web showing producers, consumers, and decomposers
Can assess overall water quality by combining chemical tests with biological indicators (macroinvertebrates)
Can analyze habitat health indicators: canopy cover, understory density, invasive species presence, edge effects
Can explain ecological succession stages and predict how a disturbed area will recover
Can compare two ecosystems and explain differences in biodiversity, productivity, and resilience
Can evaluate how human activities (development, pollution, recreation) affect local ecosystems
Can design a long-term ecological monitoring plan with sampling schedules, indicator species, and data protocols
Can design a habitat restoration plan addressing species selection, timeline, success metrics, and adaptive management
